results.justification: The document states: "We examined trace data from a graduate-level data analytics course to understand events...The study adopted a task-centric learning analytics approach..."

The document provides a detailed description of the study design, including data collection, analysis, and interpretation. Sections like 'The study adopted a task-centric learning analytics approach' and subsequent paragraphs outline the steps.
The document does not state that the raw or processed datasets are publicly available.

The document states: "We obtained an opt-out consent of participation from the university ethics committee...No students chose to exercise their ethical right to opt out.", implying privacy concerns prevent open data sharing.
Table 1 provides a categorization of JupyterLab telemetry events, serving as a data dictionary.

The document details data collection: "trace data from a data analytics learning platform...code execution, encountering errors, navigation patterns, and copying and pasting behaviour...JupyterLab telemetry plugin."

The document states: "The JupyterLab telemetry plugin was developed by the Educational Technology Collective group at the University of Michigan. Source code can be found at https: //github.com/educational-technology-collective/etc_jupyterlab_telemetry_library."
Code is shared, so this criterion is not applicable.
The document mentions data preprocessing (excluding 'save_notebook' events) but does not share the code used for this preparation.
The document describes the use of network analysis and statistical summaries (mean, standard deviation) of event counts.
While descriptive statistics are present, effect sizes, confidence intervals, and p-values are not reported.
The document provides subjective context and interpretation of the observed behaviours, categorizing them into 'Engagement-Oriented', 'Answer-Seeking', and 'Disengagement-Oriented' behaviours.
While the categorization of behaviours is described, the specific coding process and analysis details are not fully shared.
The results are presented through descriptions of observed patterns, network diagrams (Figure 4), and individual student activity patterns (Figure 3).

The document acknowledges limitations: "While this study did not directly measure curiosity...", and discusses the potential for the categorised behaviours not fully capturing the complexity of curiosity.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
